events.title: 6th Indian Division Arrives in Basra to Relieve Forces in Khuzistan and West Iran
events.description: The Headquarters of the 6th Indian Division (Major-General J. N. Thomson) arrived at Basra on 12th September with the 27th Indian Infantry Brigade, and was ordered to relieve the 8th and roth Indian Divisions in Khuzistan and West Iran respectively.

events.title: Garrison Commander Surrenders as Assault Preparations Intensify
events.description: sector of-the perimeter and preparations for the assault were put in hand. On the 12th September the garrison commander surtendered.

events.title: Air Forces Outline Key Objectives at September 12th Strategy Meeting
events.description: 377. The chief meeting took place on 12th September, and at this meeting the principal tasks of the air forces were assigned. These tasks were:

events.title: Gallant Defense Crumbles: Italian Forces Invade British Somaliland Amidst Colonial Strife
events.description: . 25. Meanwhile in French Somaliland General Legentilhomme had found himself unable, in spite of his gallant efforts, to induce the Colony to continue to fight. The Italians were thus enabled to concentrate the whole weight of their very numerous forces in the East of Italian East Africa against British Somaliland, which they invaded early in August. The operations, which resulted in the temporary loss of British Somaliland, have already been described in a despatch dated 12th September, 1940.

events.title: Air Power: Key to Defeating Japanese Forces in Southeast Asia by War's End
events.description: 1. Air Power's contribution to the overthrow of Japanese land forces during the closing stages of the war in South East Asia, is reviewed in this Despatch, which opens with the period following the Allied Forces  victorious entry into Rangoon on 3rd May, 1945, and culminates in the official surrender of the Japanese Southern Army to Admiral The  Lord Louis Mountbatten, at Singapore, on 12th September, 1945,

events.description: 1. Air Power's contribution to the overthrow of Japanese land forces during the closing stages of the war in South East Asia, is reviewed in this Despatch, which opens with the period following the Allied Forces  victorious entry into Rangoon on 3rd May, 1945, and culminates in the official surrender of the Japanese Southern Army to Admiral The  Lord Louis Mountbatten, at Singapore, on 12th September, 1945,

events.title: Historic Surrender Signed: General Itagaki Accepts Unconditional Terms in Singapore
events.description: 344. With the Supreme Allied Commander, and other Commanders-in-Chief, it afforded considerable satisfaction to witness General Itagaki sign, for his defeated compatriots, Admiral Mountbatten's terms for Unconditional Surrender in the South East Asia Theatre a Singapore, on 12th September, 1945. .

events.title: Historical Dispatch: General Wavell Submits Key Report to War Secretary, September 1940
events.description: The following despatch was submitted to the Secretary of State jor War on 12th September, 1940, by General Sir ARCHIBALD P. WAVELL, K.C.B., C.M.G., M.C., Commander-in-Chief in the Middle East.

events.title: Cloud Cover Sabotages Air Defense: Convoy's Veil Delays Enemy's Target Practice Ahead of Major Assault
events.description: 41. The convoy was first sighted by an enemy aircraft late on 8th September, but was not shadowed until 12th September. This immunity was due to clouds and low visibility ; but it did not unduly disturb the enemy, for his U-boats were in contact and shadowing from 10th September onwards. It did, however, prevent the early and comparatively small scale air attacks which had been directed against previous convoys; and thus had the unexpected and unfortunate result of depriving the guns and fighters of the practice and experience which would have helped them to deal with the first massed attack.
